dlgPart.npc_text:
デラーは老いてくたびれた書記のように見え、外見はあまりあてにならないのだということを証明している。彼は１７歳でキャラバンの護衛になった。それから３年後、彼は父親の真面目な仕事に関しての考えは間違っているのではないかと気付いて寝返り、昨日まで自分が護衛していたキャラバンを略奪し始めた。４年後、商人ギルドは帝国衛兵に莫大な金を払い、”略奪者問題”はすぐに解決した。何百人もの略奪者の死体がマードランの城壁に打ち付けられ、幸運にも生き残った少数の人間は、ギルドの負債を埋め合わせるために鉱山に送られた。１０年ほどの間デラーは鉄鉱石を採掘し、残飯を得るために、そして生きるために戦っていたが、その後テロンへ逃げ延びてアンティダスの保護を得た。
デラーは無表情で君を見ている。君が近づいてくると彼は止まるように身振りで示し、しばらくの間じろじろと観察してきた。「何の用だ？」彼は君が来た目的を推測し損ね、純粋に興味を持った様子で尋ねた。

dlgPart.npc_text: 「いい質問だ。定期的にマードランから補給を受けるにしちゃ遠すぎるし、奴らはこの土地で生活することにも慣れてない。聞き込みでもしたら何か見つかるかもな」

dlgAnsw.text: [impersonate]「奴らはソフラーブを待ってると言った<na/><mu/wa></ne>？」

dlgAnsw.text: [impersonate]「奴らはソフラーブを待ってると言った<na/><mu/wa></ne>？」
「他に何かできることはある<ka/mu>？」

dlgPart.npc_text: デラーは興味深げに君を見て、うなずく。「ソフラーブはバクトリア人だ。だから東部訛りで話す必要があるだろうな。奴は大半の時間を仕事場で過ごしているから、奴らが知ってるのは名前だけだろう。もちろん、それらしい格好をしなければいけないだろうが、ローブがあれば大丈夫だろう」

dlgAnsw.text: 「他に何かできることはある<ka/mu>？」

dlgPart.npc_text: 「まあ、この問題がお気に召さなかったんなら、二つ目のも絶対気に入らないだろうがな。我々の貴族の一人が略奪者の一団に捕まったんだ。誰かがそこへ言って略奪者達が何を望んでいるのか知る必要がある」

dlgAnsw.text: 「彼らは何が欲しいか言わなかったの<ka/mu>？」

dlgPart.npc_text: 「それが笑える話でな。数日前に略奪者の一人が入ってきて、一味が領主を捕らえたと言って要求を始めた。俺たちはそのクソ野郎の言うことを真に受けずに射撃訓練の的にしたわけだ。それからアンティダス卿の遠縁が本当に行方不明だと判明したんだが、もう手遅れだった。俺の部下はもうそこへ行って血の贖いをしようという奴はいない」

dlgPart.npc_text: [charisma failure]「他にやること探しな、<charname>」

[charisma success]"There is nothing to tell. I was young and good with a sword. I took a job guarding caravans. You know... see the world, kill a few men, make a few coins. The romance of the wasteland.
"Turned out it was just another shit job for shit pay. I worked it for three years and then decided that maybe it was time to switch sides."

"Nothing happens just like that. You ever worked caravans? Good men are expensive, so the merchant guilds hire what comes cheap – kids, rejects, cutthroats. They start dropping like flies after an attack or two, which means less sleep and more shit to deal with for those who live. You are always up, always working. You and the slaves who pull those damn carts. After awhile you start wondering who has it easier – you or the slaves."

"A sword to my throat – the most convincing argument there is.
"We were doing a two-week run. A few days in, we hit a storm. The sand was everywhere. You couldn't see anything, couldn't even open your eyes. The boss man told us to press on and we did. To be fair, nobody thought that we could be attacked in that storm.
"The raiders picked our men off one by one. By the time we'd realized what was happening, it was too late. They gave me a chance to live and I took it. Didn't even have to think about it."

"We raided for a few years. Those were the good days... If I was smarter I would have quit when I was ahead, but I was young and thought that we were a force to be reckoned with. And we were, until the merchants paid the Imperial Guards to put us out of business.
"They sent me to the iron mines. I did ten years in a place called the Second Chance. It was like a big empty pot - called the town - with passages going off in every direction. The main ore deposits were long gone, but you could find a bit here and there. That's what the tunnels were for. Every day you trade ore for food. No ore, no food. It's a simple system that brings the best out of people."
"I waited for an opportunity since the day they put me there. Only took ten years..."

dlgAnsw.text: "Have you thought of going back to raiding?"

dlgPart.npc_text:
"I have. I've also thought about going back to the mines. I believe that one comes with the other, and it's the other that I'm not looking forward to.
"There are three ways to make a living if you're good with a sword. You can do it for nothing – guarding caravans or fighting for the Imperials Guards. You can do it for yourself and sooner or later you'll piss off someone who will swat you like a fly and that would be the end of it. Or you can do it smart and work for someone like Antidas – he needs me as much as I need him. He goes up, I go up with him. He goes down – well, nobody lives forever."

dlgPart.npc_text: "Didn't take you for a poisoner. Well, Coltan owes me a favor, so now it would be a good time to collect. Wait a bit, I'll send someone to fetch it for you."
"Here you go," says Dellar, giving you a small vial. "I was assured it was the best, which is highly doubtful but better than nothing."
END - shanty
